dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Generally in five levels, level five is the ultimate master, the person that's played the game 20, 30 years, has the highest pedigree. Actually, that's you in this case, and we're still on level four because computers have been better than humans at chess for like 30 years. How has it changed the way you approach the game?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, I mean, I think chess players are using computers intensively all the time. Obviously, with material odds, it's gonna be one part of the training, and other part of the training that I find interesting is like, you know, to find positions from, let's say, real life tournaments. And I've been doing that actually from this recent tournament that's going on in Isle of Man, playing out some of those fascinating positions and just seeing what the computer does, and he's like coming up with resources that you would never think of, you know?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Today, we've been talking a lot about how chess is kind of a mix of tactics versus strategy. Let's elevate that discussion. So what is chess to you?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Well, the way my coach explained chess to me that really seems intuitive is that chess is a game of time, space, and harmony. You have one turn to get things done, right? Obviously you try to make it as efficient as possible. We have the saying in chess that, you know, you lost by one tempo, by one move. Space. You know, we have a game of 64 squares, right? So control over these 64 squares is what the game is about. You can get control in moving up your pawns. You can get control by winning opponent's material, right? So obviously, that's another big element that we're fighting over, and harmony is basically like you got this army of pieces, right? Your job is to make them work well with each other, coordinate them, and build that beautiful picture of harmony that, you know, all chess players aim for and are so pleased when they can finally achieve.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So I've never thought of chess that way. This is very interesting to me. So of those three, what would you say is the one that you have more mastery over than the other?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Harmony trumps everything. Like you could be winning when it's not your turn, and you're like totally behind on material. So it shows you that harmony is the end goal. Chess is a miniature life.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: I always like to say that chess exposes all of your flaws on the board.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Oh yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: in your training habits, in the way you approach certain positions. So you say you can see yourself on the chess board. Who is Irina on the chess board?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, well, I think Irina is a fighter. You know, Irina is not someone who likes to give up. Irina is someone who wants to leave everything on the board, right? Like every last drop. That's the idea. How do you see yourself as a player?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: I think I like to be creative. So I find fun in chess by learning 10 different openings, trying different positions. I like chaotic positions. I like positions where I can attack. I like positions where I'm getting attacked and I can maybe defend and find some creative way to turn things around, and I really, really struggle when I need to sit there and just do nothing.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: So, you know, we have opposite styles, Levy. I think our blitz game is gonna be a lot of fun. All right. If I had to guess, I'd guess you're a King's Indian player.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: No. See, that's an opening that requires a lot of time and practice and dedication, but I'll play

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Oh wow.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: something also still fun.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: All right. Okay.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Dutch defense.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Is that the Leningrad?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: I think G6 is Leningrad. I've tried to find a name. I don't actually know the name of this one. I guess there's also like the Stonewall, right? You can play.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah. All right, let's go for the most solid move.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: That's not fun.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: We don't want double pawns.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: No, we don't. I would've liked double pawns.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Okay, let's complete that bishop Fiancetto.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: I play like a lot of openings poorly. That's my approach to chess. I just play things that I think will be fun. Then the game starts going, and I'm like, Why did I play this? I should learn real openings. Okay, I guess I'll... Yeah, this is nice and boring.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Prefer it wasn't boring.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Hmm, I think I gotta do something like on the queen side here before you get your E5 move in.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, I was debating playing

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: A5, yeah. But question is, is E5 a good move or a bad move? There's only one way to find out, so.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, you're gonna go for it, yeah. All right, well I gotta take you.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Can I take with the pawn? Probably.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: E5 looks a little dangerous, but I guess we can analyze that later. All right, so what are you threatening? At the moment, not much, yeah? If I take an E5, it gets very boring. Now it's a good thing that like my queen is not gonna hang when you take my knight.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yes. Well, actually, it's not a good thing. I would've preferred that it might, you know, it might hang, but oh, we only have like 90 seconds. We have to make conversation and also play some semi-decent moves.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: That's what streamers do, right? Like Naka. [laughs] Awesome.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: I do YouTube, you know? Okay. I think we can-

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, I gotta save my queen. So we're gonna recapture like that.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: What if I do this? What if I just don't acknowledge what you're trying to do?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: That's interesting, right? 'Cause I don't have A3. I can play B5. Five's kind of interesting.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: That's a good point.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, hmm. I have C6, but you can play B6. I can take on D6. Looks a little boring but possible.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: The average chess player would want like five more minutes now. Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I think this move's kind of interesting, so we're gonna go for that.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Okay. It's a pawn sacrifice.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, sort of temporary, but I'm trying to keep your rook closed.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yes, I take, right?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah. I feel like that's- So we're trying to get the pawn back. I think this idea to keep talking during the game was really good by me.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yes. I play-

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I strategize before the game started.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: I play best when I have no time on the clock.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: So if I take an F7, you take with the king, so I don't really get anywhere with that, so I guess I gotta take this pawn. So I was going for this position. I kind of like it.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Okay. I think my plan here was to go here.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Then your C7 pawn is kind of stuck forever unless I get the tempo on your rook. Oh, bishop D5 is always an idea, too. Oh. Wow. I think you got some issues here, Levy.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: I think you should just think for like 47 more seconds, and then you should make your decision.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: All right. Hmm. I mean, I have some really tempting moves here.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: This was just information overload. You just give too many possibilities and then-

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: All right, all right. It's kind of hard to decide here. Let's not try not to win the game right away. Wow, that surprised me. You're stacking the exchange? All right.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yes, I will.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Do we just go for counter play? Maybe going for counter play was not very smart. Maybe it was like very not smart.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Hmm, wow. Okay, so I guess we should bring the rooks in.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: This is the most fun part of the game, when you have four seconds. You just have to

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Very fun. Okay. Does this one look really terrible? Let's just do it.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Now the game could theoretically go, oops, sorry.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: It's okay.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: It's no fun. No!

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Took a really important pawn there.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: No!

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Oh.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And that pawn is also really important. Why would you take both of my really important pawns?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, yeah, yeah. Okay.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: [sighs] And I lost on time. Double whammy.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: That was exciting though. This was probably my best move of the game, right?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: In taking my rook, yes.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And B5, I think so-

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Well, this is the subtle stuff, Levy, that we, you know, build a game out of.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, but I think-

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, but it's ugly. It's ugly because just in general, like this position, I think, is kind of ugly.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: You know? You're stuck with this pawn. You're stuck with this pawn.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: But question.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Weaker king.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Should you play A4? Because if you don't play A4 now, can I play A4? Can you play A4?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, that's a question. I mean, okay, like, so like, you mean if I let you play a move like that, I still think like you're gonna-

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: 'Cause I still feel like now I-

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: You're gonna have like more problems. Like even if I have like a pawn here, it's still annoying.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: But then if I start generating some-

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Some play. Yeah, you can try. A little trap.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Do you see it? Do you see it? Do you see that bishop?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: This position is not fun.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: It's tough because you got some issues with the king, some issues with the rook, with the pawns, you know? But I think, yeah, like in terms of-

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: It just exposes who you are as a person. I just have many issues. That's what-

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Your move was interesting, and it kind of posed this big decision in front of me. Right? Like over here. So I think in terms of like strategy, this was really the key moment strategically because I have to like make this big decision with the pawn structure, and so this one kind of prevented your rook from opening up on this file, and I keep my pressure on the queen side.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So this is a perfect example of time, space, and harmony all in one move.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, that's right, that's right. We're fighting for space. We're fighting to not let the opponent build harmony.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, B5 I didn't even consider. I just thought you would either take or push or-

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: But yeah, this game went more in my style, Levy. I listened to you carefully talk about all the things that you liked about chess

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: and I tried. I thought, Okay.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: It always happens.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Now I know what to do against him.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: That's what always happens. Okay, I have a personal question now.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: You are the eight-time United States women's chess champion. You also have the highest title in all of chess grandmaster. I'm an eternal runner up. Like what is the championship mentality, and how have you succeeded at it so many times?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: In terms of the grand title, that's like, I think, everyone's personal journey, right? It can take some people longer. I actually did it very late in my life. I don't know, Levy, if you know this, but I made grandmaster when I was 29. Most people, if they don't do it by the time they're like 20, they'll probably never do it. In terms of becoming a grandmaster, really, that's the time and the commitment. I think if you're an international master like you are, like everything is within reach. Like you've already played chess long enough in your life. You're close enough to that level that, really, it's gonna be little things like putting in the time, going to the best tournaments, and getting the best competition, and just maybe getting a good coach to help you as well. So it's not too late, Levy.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: We are gonna look forward to Gotham Chess making grandmaster.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, then I'll retire and, I don't know, do horse racing or something.
